bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George C. Kellogg, January 8, 1942

div1.p: Hench thanks Kellogg for the copy of the Cornwell portrait for George Carroll. He invites Kellogg to see the yellow fever exhibit at the Mayo Clinic library.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George C. Kellogg, January 8, 1942

opener.dateline:
January 8, 1942 Mr. George C. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.

div1.p:
Thank you kindly for having a framed picture sent to me in Washington
to give to Carroll's son. I am sure he will be glad to have it. Thanks also
for the clipping regarding Matas in Havana. He must have had a swell time.
He is a grand gentleman.

By the way, in your letter and in the carbon copies also you referred
to Hauberry instead of Hanberry. Remember it is Hanberry and he is mentioned
as one of the representatives in the painting.

I am sure that you and Alvarez will have a good time together. I
only wish I were here to see you again. While you are here, be sure to go
up to the Mayo Clinic library, introduce yourself to Mr. Tom Keys or Miss
Pliefke, tell them who you are and be sure to have them show you our yellow
exhibit, with Cornwell's painting, the Cuban sketches, etc. on display.
They have been up about a month and will be up a month or so longer.

You say that you hope to get in touch with us at the Hotel Roosevelt
in New York “on my return from Louisville this weekend.” I am afraid you
misunderstood me and I hasten to tell you that Mary (Mrs. Hench) and I will
be at the Hotel Roosevelt, arriving this Friday, but I will leave Sunday after-
noon for Atlantic City. She will stay in New York and then meet me in Washing-
ton on Tuesday, January 13. I don't want you to be making a trip to New York
or even to the hotel without seeing us.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
